newsitem.title: USA: Union leaders to fight Chrysler pact - WSJ.
newsitem.headline: Union leaders to fight Chrysler pact - WSJ.

text.p: Certain United Auto Worker union leaders will ask workers to reject a tentative contract agreement reached with Chrysler Corp, the Wall Street Journal said in Thursday's electronic edition.
Chrysler and union bargainers said on Wednesday they reached a tentative pact to end a month-old engine plant strike that paralyzed production of some of the automaker's most profitable vehicles.
But the Journal reported four of the top eight local union leaders walked out of Wednesday's bargaining session refusing to sign the tentative pact they called a "cave-in."
UAW members went on strike demanding Chrysler drop plans to shift production of drive shafts to Toledo-Ohio based Dana Corp . The union said the transfer would cost 300 jobs.

Union members close to the protesting leaders were quoted by the Journal as saying they were unhappy with Chrysler's failure to meet some demands, including a request for $300,000 in penalty payments for the assignment of work previously done at the plant to outside suppliers.
A Chrysler spokesman was quoted as saying he was not familiar with the issue.
"Chrysler owes our members and they basically got away without giving them anything," Richard Webster, the shop chairman of UAW local 51, was quoted as saying.
He and other members would abstain from endorsing the pact, the newspaper said.
